previous.name: The Culmination of the Spiritual Life

segments.pli: Saṃyutta Nikāya 55
segments.en: Linked Discourses 55

segments.pli: 1. Veḷudvāravagga
segments.en: 1. At Bamboo Gate

segments.pli: 3. Dīghāvuupāsakasutta
segments.en: 3. With Dīghāvu

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena dīghāvu upāsako ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
segments.en: Now at that time the lay follower Dhīgāvu was sick, suffering, gravely ill.

segments.pli: Atha kho dīghāvu upāsako pitaraṃ jotikaṃ gahapatiṃ āmantesi:
segments.en: Then he addressed his father, the householder Jotika,

segments.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, gahapati, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena bhagavato pāde sirasā vanda:
segments.en: “Please, householder, go to the Buddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him:

segments.pli: ‘dīghāvu, bhante, upāsako ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
segments.en: ‘Sir, the lay follower Dhīgāvu is sick, suffering, gravely ill.

segments.pli: So bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatī’ti.
segments.en: He bows with his head to your feet.’

segments.pli: Evañca vadehi:
segments.en: And then say:

segments.pli: ‘sādhu kira, bhante, bhagavā yena dīghāvussa upāsakassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā’”ti.
segments.en: ‘Sir, please visit him at his home out of compassion.’”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, tātā”ti kho jotiko gahapati dīghāvussa upāsakassa paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho jotiko gahapati bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: “Yes, dear,” replied Jotika. He did as Dīghāvu asked.

segments.pli: “dīghāvu, bhante, upāsako ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
So bhagavato pāde sirasā vandati.
Evañca vadeti:
‘sādhu kira, bhante, bhagavā yena dīghāvussa upāsakassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā’”ti.
Adhivāsesi bhagavā tuṇhībhāvena.
segments.en: The Buddha consented in silence.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena dīghāvussa upāsakassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi. Nisajja kho bhagavā dīghāvuṃ upāsakaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of the lay follower Dīghāvu, sat down on the seat spread out, and said to him,

segments.pli: “kacci te, dīghāvu, khamanīyaṃ, kacci yāpanīyaṃ? Kacci dukkhā vedanā paṭikkamanti, no abhikkamanti; paṭikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no abhikkamo”ti?
segments.en: “I hope you’re coping, Dīghāvu; I hope you’re getting better. I hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”

segments.pli: “Na me, bhante, khamanīyaṃ, na yāpanīyaṃ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo”ti.
segments.en: “Sir, I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.”

segments.pli: “Tasmātiha te, dīghāvu, evaṃ sikkhitabbaṃ:
segments.en: “So, Dīghāvu, you should train like this:

segments.pli: ‘buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato bhavissāmi—itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.
segments.en: ‘I will have experiential confidence in the Buddha …

segments.pli: Dhamme … pe …
segments.en: the teaching …

segments.pli: saṅghe … pe …
segments.en: the Saṅgha …

segments.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato bhavissāmi akhaṇḍehi … pe … samādhisaṃvattanikehi’.
segments.en: And I will have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.’

segments.pli: Evañhi te, dīghāvu, sikkhitabban”ti.
segments.en: That’s how you should train.”

segments.pli: “Yānimāni, bhante, bhagavatā cattāri sotāpattiyaṅgāni desitāni, saṃvijjante dhammā mayi, ahañca tesu dhammesu sandissāmi.
segments.en: “Sir, these four factors of stream-entry that were taught by the Buddha are found in me, and I am seen in them.

segments.pli: Ahañhi, bhante, buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato—itipi so bhagavā … pe … satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.
segments.en: For I have experiential confidence in the Buddha …

segments.pli: Dhamme … pe …
segments.en: the teaching …

segments.pli: saṅghe … pe …
segments.en: the Saṅgha …

segments.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato akhaṇḍehi … pe … samādhisaṃvattanikehī”ti.
segments.en: And I have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.”

segments.pli: “Tasmātiha tvaṃ, dīghāvu, imesu catūsu sotāpattiyaṅgesu patiṭṭhāya cha vijjābhāgiye dhamme uttari bhāveyyāsi.
segments.en: “In that case, Dīghāvu, grounded on these four factors of stream-entry you should further develop these six things that play a part in realization.

segments.pli: Idha tvaṃ, dīghāvu, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassī viharāhi, anicce dukkhasaññī, dukkhe anattasaññī pahānasaññī virāgasaññī nirodhasaññīti.
segments.en: You should meditate observing the impermanence of all conditions, perceiving suffering in impermanence, perceiving not-self in suffering, perceiving giving up, perceiving fading away, and perceiving cessation.

segments.pli: Evañhi te, dīghāvu, sikkhitabban”ti.
segments.en: That’s how you should train.”

segments.pli: “Yeme, bhante, bhagavatā cha vijjābhāgiyā dhammā desitā, saṃvijjante dhammā mayi, ahañca tesu dhammesu sandissāmi.
segments.en: “These six things that play a part in realization that were taught by the Buddha are found in me, and I embody them.

segments.pli: Ahañhi, bhante, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassī viharāmi, anicce dukkhasaññī, dukkhe anattasaññī pahānasaññī virāgasaññī nirodhasaññī.
segments.en: For I meditate observing the impermanence of all conditions, perceiving suffering in impermanence, perceiving not-self in suffering, perceiving giving up, perceiving fading away, and perceiving cessation.

segments.pli: Api ca me, bhante, evaṃ hoti:
segments.en: But still, sir, I think,

segments.pli: ‘mā hevāyaṃ jotiko gahapati mamaccayena vighātaṃ āpajjī’”ti.
segments.en: ‘I hope Jotika doesn’t suffer grief when I’ve gone.’”

segments.pli: “Mā tvaṃ, tāta dīghāvu, evaṃ manasākāsi.
segments.en: Jotika said, “Dear Dīghāvu, don’t focus on that.

segments.pli: Iṅgha tvaṃ, tāta dīghāvu, yadeva te bhagavā āha, tadeva tvaṃ sādhukaṃ manasi karohī”ti.
segments.en: Come on, dear Dīghāvu, you should closely focus on what the Buddha is saying.”

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā dīghāvuṃ upāsakaṃ iminā ovādena ovaditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
segments.en: When the Buddha had given this advice he got up from his seat and left.

segments.pli: Atha kho dīghāvu upāsako acirapakkantassa bhagavato kālamakāsi.
segments.en: Not long after the Buddha left, Dīghāvu passed away.

segments.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
segments.en: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

segments.pli: “yo so, bhante, dīghāvu nāma upāsako bhagavatā saṃkhittena ovādena ovadito so kālaṅkato.
segments.en: “Sir, the lay follower named Dīghāvu, who was advised in brief by the Buddha, has passed away.

segments.pli: Tassa kā gati, ko abhisamparāyo”ti?
segments.en: Where has he been reborn in his next life?”

segments.pli: “Paṇḍito, bhikkhave, dīghāvu upāsako, paccapādi dhammassānudhammaṃ, na ca maṃ dhammādhikaraṇaṃ vihesesi.
segments.en: “Mendicants, the lay follower Dīghāvu was astute. He practiced in line with the teachings, and did not trouble me about the teachings.

segments.pli: Dīghāvu, bhikkhave, upāsako pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātiko tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā”ti.
segments.en: With the ending of the five lower fetters, he’s been reborn spontaneously, and will become extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.”

segments.pli: Tatiyaṃ.

sections.title: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha,…

suttaplex.blurb: The lay follower Dīghāvu is ill and he asks for the Buddha to visit. Dīghāvu confirms that he possesses the four factors of stream-entry and in addition six contemplations leading to insight. Yet he is still worried that his close companion will miss him when he dies.
